message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance and the dermatomal distribution of the paresthesias, suggest that the most likely cause is C5-C6 disc herniation. Carpal tunnel syndrome would not produce weakness in the wrist, and Syringomyelia would produce more widespread symptoms. Thoracic outlet syndrome might cause paresthesias in the upper extremity, but not weakness in the wrist. The positive brachioradialis reflex indicates a localized lesion to C5-C6 nerve root.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest cervical radiculopathy, which is most commonly caused by a C5-C6 herniated disc. The weakness of the left wrist extension is consistent with this diagnosis. Nerve compression in other areas, such as the wrist (carpal tunnel syndrome) or the thoracic outlet (thoracic outlet syndrome), would not cause these specific symptoms. Syringomyelia is a rare disorder that can lead to a range of neurological symptoms, but it is unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a cervical radiculopathy, with pain radiating to the arm and paresthesias in the hand. Weakness when extending the wrist against resistance suggests a C5-C6 disc herniation. Carpal tunnel syndrome would cause paresthesias in the median nerve distribution, not the radial nerve. Syringomyelia affects the spinal cord and would not cause focal pain and paresthesias in the upper extremity. Thoracic outlet syndrome would typically cause paresthesia in the ulnar nerve distribution, not the radial nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of pain and paresthesias radiating to the left arm and hand, weakness on wrist extension, and positive Spurling sign are indicative of a cervical radiculopathy, which is often caused by C5-C6 disc herniation. Carpal tunnel syndrome would have pain and paresthesias restricted to the median nerve distribution, while syringomyelia would have sensory deficits in a cape-like distribution. Thoracic outlet syndrome would have sensory deficits in the ulnar nerve distribution and possible vascular symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a nerve root compression, and specifically, the distribution of pain and weakness suggests C5-C6 disc herniation. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is characterized by pain and paresthesias in the median nerve distribution. Syringomyelia is a spinal cord disorder that is not characterized by radicular pain. Thoracic Outlet Syndrome is characterized by pain and paresthesias in the ulnar nerve distribution.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient describes symptoms of left neck, shoulder, and arm pain that radiates to the radial aspect of her left forearm, thumb, and index finger. When she extends and rotates her head to the left and downward pressure is applied, she reports paresthesias along the radial aspect of her left forearm and thumb. These symptoms suggest a C5-C6 disc herniation, which can lead to compression of the nerve roots that supply the upper limb. The weakness when extending the left wrist against resistance further supports this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a nerve impingement, and the weakness in extending the left wrist against resistance suggests involvement of the C5-C6 nerve roots. Carpal tunnel syndrome affects the median nerve and does not involve the C5-C6 nerve roots. Syringomyelia is a spinal cord disorder and would have additional neurological symptoms. Thoracic outlet syndrome would involve the brachial plexus and present with weakness and sensory deficits in the hand.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a C5-C6 disc herniation, which can cause radiculopathy and weakness in the muscles innervated by the affected nerve roots. The positive findings on physical examination also support this diagnosis. Carpal tunnel syndrome primarily affects the median nerve and does not involve weakness in wrist extension. Syringomyelia would typically have more widespread neurologic findings, and thoracic outlet syndrome would involve more compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus rather than the C5-C6 nerve roots.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The left neck, shoulder, and arm pain with paresthesias and weakness suggest a cervical radiculopathy. The location of symptoms and the weakness of extending the left wrist suggests a C5-C6 disc herniation as the most likely diagnosis among the options. Carpal tunnel syndrome would not cause weakness and would only affect the hand. Syringomyelia and thoracic outlet syndrome also have different symptoms and signs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest C5-C6 disc herniation, which can cause radiculopathy and weakness in the distribution mentioned. Carpal tunnel syndrome can cause paresthesias in a similar distribution but doesn't cause weakness or reflex changes. Syringomyelia can also cause paresthesias but usually presents with sensory deficits, muscle wasting and loss of reflexes. Thoracic outlet syndrome can also cause similar symptoms but is usually associated with vascular rather than neurological symptoms.
